references: Table 1 illustrates the properties of our proposed method and provides a comparison between our algorithm and underlying analysis with related seminal works. As shown in this table, building upon the results in [17, 13], we extend the capability of FL to staleness. Table 1 also contains the convergence results for our proposed algorithm, which we will discuss in more details in Section 4.

The proof of this theorem can be found in Appendix B.
Theorem 2 shows a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1T)+𝒪​(τ2T)+𝒪​(α2​σg2b)𝒪1𝑇𝒪superscript𝜏2𝑇𝒪superscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\tau^{2}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) for PersA-FL algorithm under MAML setup. Now, let us compare this rate with the convergence rate of FedAsync and Per-FedAvg, as in Table 1. The last term in the above rate, i.e., 𝒪​(α2​σg2b)𝒪superscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2𝑏\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\alpha^{2}\sigma_{g}^{2}}{b}\right) accounts for personalization with biased gradient estimation. Moreover, compared to Per-FedAvg, the second term of this rate is different, which accounts for the maximum delay in asynchronous updates.
